There are no clouds in sight by me
Ugh, I need to take my car to a car wash today :/
Still has salt on it, it's been above 40 for a few days, and tomorrow hits 70+, followed by 60+ for the next week or so
Took my car to the carwash on Friday, went in looking like a grey car with white bottom, came out a shinny black car
Pro tip, don't use soft-touch car washes
Over time it'll ruin the paint job
Touchless for powdered coatings, hand-wash for anything heavier.
This is my source, might check out some videos later that claim the opposite :P
yeah, even things like hand-buffers will create paint swirls overtime
honestly buffers maybe even after the 1st/2nd time
What did I miss last night?
dunno, just lots of cute stuff
Understandable. Man's been working his backside off over the past year or so
I had a bit of a surprise when I found out how old that AU was...along with Male Kathrin (Which was adorable)
My best friend first told me about the comic in 2016, shortly after I discovered Mark
I think during a lot of the post-kickstart era streams
I looked at one page...where Kathrin's saved by Natani from the ship. I thought it was a mine. Didn't really manage to read it till 2017 (same year I discovered Halo and Warhammer 40k)
...it might be one of the biggest things in my life for the past few years
somehow, as soon as I built a computer I found my way here shortly after.
Though I must admit the first few chapters haven't aged well.
oddly, I joined around the giant Natani confusion era.
I love Twokinds to bits, but it's clear that Tom was still trying to figure out what he was actually  writing up to about the Basitin Arc
Seriously, every time I read that Arc, it strikes such a RESONANCE.
Especially Keith and Alaric's duel on the bridge, and the Trial with the generals.
"How dare you Blaspheme the law?!" "The law is not a religious doctrine!" Two of the best lines in the seriesd
yeah, a first great trial for our heroes
Highlights quite a few problems we have here as well.
Chapters 16-17 really hit as well, because of the Confessions, and especially Raine and Red's dynamic
Red honestly doesn't get enough love in the sketches, in my opinion
doesn't help the templars were sort of skewing Basitin ways a bit further
It is terrifying, however, how even that deep into madness, Trace was such a good planner.
Ironic that his own handpicked acolytes have all ended up betraying him, one way or another.
Even the dark shade of himself, Detritus, rejects their old master, considering themself more worthy of the name...
"oh crap, everyone left in my wake exposed to my ways have gone insane"
I think Tom mentioned before the plan was to have everyone travel to the Basitin Isle yet everything would have already deteriorated because of the magic use
so it could have just been a lots of demented screaming and erratic magic blasting
I'm personally glad he went for the angle he did. It allowed for a great deal more character analysis.
yup, haphazardly saved the day by being morally righteous meddlers
D'you know, the Basitins actually remind me of Ireland during the 20th century, although not to the same degree-especially from the 20s to the 60s.
Ireland back then had a similar cultural addiction to the 'Law', in this case being the Catholic Church.
Unfortunately, power corrupts, and this led to the horrific abuses that history has charted. I shall say no more of them here for now.
yeah, mostly just because societies want rules to live by to give their lives purpose and structure

But the country certainly had similar cultural prejudices and obsession with following the 'doctrine'. Even today, Irish people as a whole don't look so kindly on those who break from the norm, although it is slowly changing.
There's a reason many Irish actors and Artists are more successful overseas (Enya, The Corrs, Saoirse Ronan, etc)
it's basically just vote for the national narrative you're most comfortable with
Indeed. It probably applies to a host of countries.
The core message is there though...blind adherence to laws or rules leads to stagnation and ruin
That we NEED to think for ourselves and make choices based on our own consciences...for good or ill.
it's kinda like in Secret of the Kells, a solid societal philosophy is fundamental and superior in maintaining a unified nation
separate settlements can be divided or destroyed
Indeed! Cellach seeks safety in his walls, but fails to fortify the gate or the stairs, and when the northmen come...all burns.
"Not my wall, Aidan! A wall to save Civilisation! A wall to save your book!"
Although it's worth noting that Cellach was still trying to protect all...not just Christans, but pagans and other religions...no matter the banner, people are people.
Woah, this got real philisophical...I apologise.
yeah, just really a common ideology, mostly of mutual welfare
conquering nations in history do have instances of bringing order and prosperity though, like the mongols
though I wouldn't be surprised if it was because of tribal structure where the mongols invaded
Temujin was thorough in his integration of the nomad peoples...
like it would have brought a single ideology for people to believe and live under
I hope constantly that we'll become a less bloodthirsty species as a whole...
Then again, maybe I focus too much on the negatives...
yeah that's the thing, unifying usually is in the interest of strength in numbers so if there's no enemy... then what?
We become the enemy, that's what...
I have discovered something somewhat worrying.
As we become less openly violent in society...we as people fight over increasingly petty grievances.
